results.title: [German newsreel]
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine newsreel items including: International trade show; Axel Springer (publishing company) new headquarters situated close to the Berlin Wall; Gutenberg Museum; detailed look at modern and traditional printing techniques; Helmut A.P. Greishaber, GErmany’s leading woodcarver, at home relaxing and working; Munich’s Leopold Strasse - artist/student district; five days of leading gymnasts from 41 countries compete for World championships at Dortmunder.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film is a series of shorter films from different periods edited together. They include trips to Lake Eildon and the Eildon Weir Spillway and Dromana Beach. Streets of Ballarat and Alexandra are also briefly seen.

We see a doubles tennis tournament at Kooyong Stadium and a scene of the 1936 Australian golf exhibition tour with Gene Sarazen (USA), Jim Ferrier (Australia) and Helen Hicks (USA), the first professional female golfer in the world.

Included are members of the Parsons family, also playing tennis and golf, and towards the end of the film there is a raquet technique demonstration from Robin (George Robinson) Parsons himself.

In addition to showing fashions of the time there are brief scenes showing vehicles of the era, including a steam locomotive, ships, a row boat and horses. The two main vehicles seen are the family cars: a 1935 Chevrolet and 1933 Rover.

The film also includes a few scenes of dogs playing and doing tricks including the family terrier called Peter.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies during the period 1929 to 1938. This collection of home movies, made on a Bolex camera using 16mm AGFA film, was donated to ACMI by his nephew, Chris Parsons.

The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This short film shows the family swimming and boating.

Selected highlghts list:
00:00:02:00 family members swimming in the shallows of a river among logs
00:00:50:00 boats moored in a sheltered spot including the ‘Shenandoah’ which the family is boarding
